Problem:
Consider a hypothetical physical system where the state of the system \\( x(t) \\) is governed by the differential equation \\( \\dot{x} = Dx \\), with D being a constant matrix. We analyze the influence of changing the basis of the state vector using the transformation \\( T(x) = Px \\), where P is a matrix representing a change of basis.

If \\( T(x) \\) is applied to a vector \\( x_0 \\) at t = 0, and then allowed to evolve under \\( \\dot{x} = Dx \\) without further intervention, will \\( x(t) \\) at t = T be the basis transformed form of \\( x_0 \\) directly evolved to t = T under \\( \\dot{x} = Dx \\)?
Explanation: The transformation \\( T(x) = Px \\) alters the initial state to \\( Px_0 \\). Although both systems are governed by the same differential equation, due to the change of basis before the evolution, the resulting state vectors will not only differ by a transformation but will follow different trajectories unless P commutes with D.
